results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies during the period 1929 to 1938. This collection of home movies, made on a Bolex camera using 16mm AGFA film, was donated to ACMI by his nephew, Chris Parsons.

The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

results.title: [In the present]
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Originally part of a two-channel installation, this work presents a series of elusive narrative moments culled from snippets of ordinary life and oddly extraordinary objects. These moments gain their meaning on the periphery of perception. Writes Baldino: According to William James, the ‘present’ is about 3 to 12 seconds long; everything else is constructed memory. Each segment of In the Present is within this time frame. What you see or don’t see depends on what you remember. Your memory becomes part of the picture and distorts the idea of ‘present’ time.

results.title: [ILO Webster]
results.creator_credit: Bert Kroon, John van der Heulen and Toonder Studios
results.brief_description: Unless we all work together the great problems of over population and massive unemployment has little chance of being overcome. This animated film discusses the problems and suggests possible ways of tackling them.

results.title: [Images en negatif]
results.brief_description: An example of the use of negative film material to produce dramatic impact in film. The director, Eugene Deslaw, is one of the pioneers of the avant-garde cinema and in this film he explores the possibilities of negative photography. The result is a poem of imagination and beauty. (Awards: Diploma of Honour: Venice Film Festival, 1956)

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
It wasn’t just the Kodak factory in Coburg that produced amazing images during its hey-day. The then-industrial zone was also home to the Gadsden factory, which employed around 1000 workers in the 1960s, and specialised in can-making and packaging. The success of the business allowed two generations of Gadsden men, Stanley and his son Ronald, to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking – a relatively expensive hobby for the time.

We, and future generations, have benefited from their keen eye and passion for home movies, with a donation of films spanning the decades from the early 30s to the late 80s. The two cameramen captured the passage of time through their family, preserving a fascinating window into bygone days and customs.

Through the films we see early Melbourne, including some rare footage of a flooded Yarra River in the 1930s. Days at the beach, tennis, parties, interstate holidays and trips to the country have also been filmed, including a passion for skiing with many films in the collection featuring action both on the slopes and après–skiing at the lodge. You see the children growing up, the dapper fashions – a time when a dad and his kid in matching shirts was quite lovely.

The collection also contains a hidden gem, a short film labelled ‘de Groot’, which may be the only footage of the infamous Sydney Harbour Bridge Opening ribbon cutter – wielding a sword atop a horse, Francis de Groot declared the Bridge open to the horror of the officiating party. He was unexpected and uninvited!

This collection of home movies was originally made on 8mm and 16mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 121]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gasdsen family and friends enjoying a skiing holiday at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. A particular highlight in the footage is a glimpse of the Sundeck Hotel which was built in 1959 and rebuilt in 1960 after a fire. The reel ends with shots of skiing, the snow covered mountains and buildings.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 people skiing down a slope only to fall in a heap, laughing in front of the camera
00:02:38:00 strapping on skis alongside the Sundeck Hotel
00:02:56:00 skiers jumping on a ski lift and waving at the camera as they sail by; the camera follows the lift showing it rising with the snow covered slopes
00:03:11:00 a woman and boy we saw earlier, catching the ski lift and waving at the camera
00:00:00:00 vehicle with snow tyres hauling a trailer near some buildings in deep snow

results.title: [Fred Daley Collection]
results.material_description: 8mm home movie reels (small and large). Most already digitised.
results.brief_description:
A collection of silent, 8mm home movies by steam train enthusiast Fred Daley, capturing scenes of steam trains, the Daley family, vintage cars, railway stations, and snapshots of rural and city life.

The films are mainly shot on family holidays in various locations across Victoria from the City of Melbourne to Warburton, Apollo Bay and Mornington Peninsula, to a long road trip to Cooma, New South Wales. There is also a work specially dedicated to Victoria’s most famous steam train, Puffing Billy.

Fred was a skilled filmmaker - we are presented with polished films, employing use of a tripod, nifty title sequences and astute editing. Whilst filming steam trains was his passion, made evident by the many hours of footage dedicated to them, Fred also shows the family’s love of the outdoors on summer holidays, road trips, gardens, Luna Park, a game of football at the MCG, picnics and relaxing on the beach.

The titles shown here were made from the mid-to-late 1960s but Fred’s collection spans some fifty years. Kindly donated to the ACMI Collection by Fred’s son Neville, Fred’s Films provide memories not only for his family but also for the collective memory of Victorians, steam train buffs, filmmakers, historians, or anyone who has the pleasure of watching them.

A collection of silent home movies filmed by train enthusiast Fred Daley.
Footage of:
Daley Family
Steam trains
Vintage cars
Railway stations
Family holidays
Locations across Victoria
Warburton
Echuca
Heathcote
Mornington
Tasmania
Alice Springs

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 1 x DVD, 8mm, 16mm home movies and a 35mm film strip.
results.brief_description: The Douglas Wilson Home Movie Collection contains home movies, originally made on 8mm and 16mm film, showing life in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s. Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

results.title: [Eat LOUD carpet compilation]
results.creator_credit: LOUD Media Festival of Youth Culture and the Arts
results.brief_description: A collection of four short films from the SBS program, “Eat Carpet”, in which things aren’t always as they seem. “Goth to be Greek”, directed by Andrew Georgiou and Tim Slade, is the story of a goth who finally finds a woman who wears black and hangs out in cemeteries. “Bad news”, directed by Sofya Gollan, tells the tale of a profoundly deaf couple who react in an unexpected way after hearing some news from their apologetic doctor. “Skater, homie, skeggy, wog”, directed by Andrew Dowell and Brendan Dowell, focuses on some of the myths and misconceptions that teens from rival suburbs have regarding each other’s dress and way of living. “How black is black?”, directed by Jade Woods (aged 13), looks at the identity crises suffered by fair-skinned Koories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: LOUD Media Festival of Youth Culture and the Arts

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
